Description: Limestone stela of Tunennekhebkhons: on the top of this round-topped stela is depicted a winged sun-disk carved in raised relief. Below, in sunk relief, the metal-engraver Tunennekhebkhons holds an offering before an altar piled with other offerings to the god Osiris who stands on the left. Behind the owner of the stela stands his wife the chantress of Amun Henuttaneb, with her arms raised in worship. Seven columns of texts are incised above them, and three lines of text below the scene contain a prayer to Ra-Horakhty, Osiris and Anubis on behalf of Tunennekhebkhons and his wife. There are a few gouges along the edges and on the surface. The lower right side has become darker than the rest of the stela. There are traces of red paint on the lower left edge, although this may not be original.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: The British Museum, 'A guide to the Egyptian galleries (Sculpture)' (London, 1909), 205 (no. 745); R. Moss, 'Journal of Egyptian Archaeology' 27 (1941), 9, pl. II.
Bibliographic references: Bierbrier 1993 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 12. (Pl.70-71)
Condition: The stela is well preserved apart from a few gouges along the edges and on the surface. The lower right side has become darker than the rest of the stela.
Acquisition notes: In the possession of the dealer Cureton c. 1830-40, but purchased from the Revd T. Philpot.
